title: Quiz 4: CNS & Pain Management
description: Assess your knowledge of drugs affecting the Central Nervous System, including psychotropics, anticonvulsants, and pain management strategies (Units 11-13).

questions.question: Match the CNS drug class with its representative medication:
questions.explanation: Diazepam is a benzo; Phenobarbital is a barbiturate; Chlorpromazine is a typical antipsychotic; Imipramine is a TCA.
questions.hint: Look at the suffixes: -pam, -barbital.

questions.question: Why is Aspirin contraindicated in children and teenagers recovering from viral infections like chickenpox or influenza?

options.text: It causes severe gastric bleeding in children.
It increases the risk of Reye's Syndrome.
It is ineffective against fever in this age group.

questions.explanation: Aspirin is linked to Reye's Syndrome (a rare but serious condition causing liver and brain swelling) when given to children/teens with viral infections.
questions.hint: This syndrome affects the liver and brain.

questions.question: Which of the following are critical nursing assessments prior to administering Morphine Sulfate? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Morphine causes respiratory depression, CNS depression, pinpoint pupils, and constipation. Glucose is not typically affected by narcotics directly.
questions.hint: Think about the 'depressing' effects of narcotics.

questions.question: What is the specific narcotic antagonist used to reverse respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose?
questions.explanation: Naloxone (Narcan) blocks opioid receptors and reverses effects like respiratory depression.
questions.hint: Starts with 'N'.

questions.question: Patients taking Lithium Carbonate must maintain adequate intake of ___BLANK___ and fluids to prevent toxicity.
questions.explanation: Lithium toxicity is enhanced by sodium depletion (hyponatremia) and dehydration. The body holds onto Lithium when Sodium is low.
questions.hint: A common electrolyte found in table salt.

questions.question: Review the Toxicity Table below. Which symptom cluster describes 'Salicylism' (chronic aspirin toxicity)?

richContent.content:
ConditionSymptoms
Opioid OverdosePinpoint pupils, respiratory depression, coma
Acetaminophen ToxicityHepatic damage, malaise, nausea, vomiting
Salicylism???

options.text: Tinnitus (ringing in ears), dizziness, mental confusion

questions.explanation: Salicylism is characterized by tinnitus (ringing in the ears), difficulty hearing, dizziness, and confusion.
questions.hint: The key symptom involves the ears.

questions.question: Which anticonvulsant drug is associated with the side effect of gingival hyperplasia (overgrowth of gum tissue) and requires strict oral hygiene?
questions.explanation: Phenytoin (Dilantin) commonly causes gingival hyperplasia. Patients must practice good oral hygiene to minimize gum bleeding and overgrowth.
questions.hint: This drug also precipitates if mixed with dextrose IV.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical indications for the use of Magnesium Sulfate? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Seizures associated with toxemia of pregnancy (Eclampsia)

questions.explanation: Magnesium Sulfate is used for eclampsia seizures, epilepsy, and hypomagnesemia. It is contraindicated in heart block due to its depressant effects on conduction.
questions.hint: Commonly used in labor/delivery for seizure prophylaxis.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for managing a patient with suspected Magnesium intoxication (loss of reflexes, respiratory depression):

items.text: Assess deep tendon reflexes and respiratory rate

questions.explanation: First identify the toxicity (loss of reflexes), then stop the drug, support respiration, and give the antidote (Calcium).
questions.hint: Identify, Stop, Support, Reverse.

questions.question: What is the antidote for Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) overdose?
questions.explanation: N-acetylcysteine (Mucomyst) inactivates the toxic metabolites of acetaminophen to prevent hepatic damage.
questions.hint: Often used as a mucolytic as well.

questions.question: A patient taking Chlorpromazine (Largactil) develops muscle tremors, shuffling gait, and rigidity. What are these side effects collectively called?
questions.explanation: Extrapyramidal symptoms (Parkinsonism, dystonia, akathisia) are common side effects of phenothiazine antipsychotics due to dopamine blockade.
questions.hint: Symptoms that mimic Parkinson's disease.

questions.question: Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) has significant anti-inflammatory properties similar to Aspirin.
questions.explanation: False. Acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic but has NO significant anti-inflammatory or anti-platelet effect.
questions.hint: It treats pain and fever, but not swelling.

questions.question: Match the drug with its specific therapeutic use:
questions.explanation: Codeine suppresses cough; Carbamazepine treats nerve pain; Diazepam stops active seizures; Imipramine treats bedwetting.
questions.hint: Codeine = Cough; Imipramine = Incontinence.

questions.question: Which instruction is vital for a patient taking NSAIDs (e.g., Diclofenac, Ibuprofen) to prevent a common side effect?

options.text: Take on an empty stomach for faster action.
Take with milk or food to prevent GI irritation.
Avoid drinking water with the medication.
Crush the tablet to prevent choking.

questions.explanation: NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandins that protect the stomach lining, leading to irritation, ulcers, or bleeding. Taking them with food buffers this effect.
questions.hint: These drugs are notoriously hard on the stomach.

questions.question: Benzodiazepines like Diazepam exert their anxiolytic effect by increasing the inhibitory action of the neurotransmitter ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines enhance the effect of GABA (Gamma-aminobutyric acid), the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS.
questions.hint: A four-letter acronym.

questions.question: What is the primary risk associated with the rapid intravenous administration of Phenytoin (Dilantin)?
questions.explanation: Rapid IV administration of Phenytoin can cause cardiovascular collapse (hypotension) and arrhythmias. It must be given slowly.
questions.hint: It depresses the heart's electrical system.

questions.question: Which of the following are contraindications for the use of Narcotic Analgesics? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Narcotics increase ICP (bad for head injury), depress respiration (bad for asthma), and can lower seizure threshold. They ARE used for pain and diarrhea.
questions.hint: Avoid in conditions involving the brain's pressure or the lungs' ability to breathe.

questions.question: Barbiturates like Phenobarbital can be stopped abruptly after long-term use without any withdrawal symptoms.
questions.explanation: False. Abrupt withdrawal from barbiturates after long-term use can cause severe withdrawal symptoms, including convulsions and delirium.
questions.hint: CNS depressants usually require tapering.

questions.question: What is the common side effect of Tricyclic Antidepressants (like Clomipramine) described as 'dry mouth'?
questions.explanation: Dry mouth (Xerostomia) is a classic anticholinergic side effect of Tricyclic antidepressants.
questions.hint: Medical term starting with 'X'.

questions.question: When administering an analgesic, what is the most reliable indicator of pain?

options.text: The nurse's estimation based on the injury

questions.explanation: Pain is subjective. The patient's report is the most reliable indicator (using PQRST assessment).
questions.hint: Pain is whatever the patient says it is.
